question:
The Department of Science and Technology has put forth the draft Scientific Social Responsibility Policy. Consider the following statements in this context:
  1. The policy calls for scientists to allocate a minimum 10 days for imparting knowledge to the public.
  2. The institutions will be able to outsource their scientific social responsibility.
Which of the above statements is/are true?
explanation: Statement 1 is correct: The DST had put forth the SSR policy along the lines of Corporate Social Responsibility concept. One of its proposals is to mandate scientists to spend a minimum of 10 days imparting knowledge to the public in a year. The scientists would also have their SSR work evaluated periodically.  Statement 2 is incorrect: The scientific institutions would not be allowed to outsource their SSR work. Most of the scientific work is funded by public money. Hence, the policy seeks to give back to the society. The draft policy also proposes incentives for the scientists’ outreach activities.
